poem:
**Gleaming Troves**  

Gold beneath the waves sleeps,  
history's fingers brushing—lost  
shores, untold fortunes flame  
in ocean's grasp.

Shackleton's dreams echo, hushed  
in icy whispers.  
Men dive, seeking threads  
of the past,  
glimmering in dark depths—  
a tapestry woven  
by time and tides.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I had found gold before, but not like this’: four of the most splendid treasures salvaged from shipwrecks Treasure and shipwrecks go hand in hand – but what are the most magnificent and historically significant items ever salvaged and what do they tell us about the world we live in? The underwater archaeologist Mensun Bound, who was the director of exploration on the team that discovered Ernest Shackleton’s ship Endurance, has written a new maritime". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
